item.title: Introduction
item.description: Welcome to this course on publishing. It assumes you have some (written) work that you would like to publish.

item.title: The Two Hats
item.description: A writer who wishes to have a long, sustainable career has to wear two different hats. The first hat is obviously the writer’s hat.

item.title: How to Sell your Work I
item.description: In the previous chapter, I told you to put on the Business Hat (and take off the Writer’s Hat).

item.title: How to Sell your Work II
item.description: Previous chapter asked you to pin down your target audience and your unique selling point. This chapter is more about the specific content of your book and the marketing text you’ll add.

item.title: Traditional Publishing
item.description: This article talks about the pros and cons of traditional publishing, how the process works (in general, specific chapters come later), and the role literary agents play in there.

item.title: Query Letters
item.description: Query letters follow a relatively strict format. It’s not that you’re required to follow it, or that it’s some unwritten rule.

item.title: Synopsis
item.description: The synopsis has always been my biggest struggle. The first drafts of my stories tend to become overly complicated, with too many story threads, which makes it impossible to summarize it all in a single page.

item.title: Self-Publishing I
item.description: Earlier in the course, I discussed how traditional publishing works, plus its advantages or disadvantages. I also confessed I don’t have much experience with that.

item.title: Self-Publishing II
item.description: As promised, in this article I’ll give my reviews of the most popular self-publishing services. Where possible, I’ll include practical tips on how to use them, plus my personal statistics/data from using them.

item.title: Cover Design
item.description: Obviously, this course is not about graphic design or illustration. This chapter merely gives some basic advice on how to approach creating the right cover, using tips that anyone can execute (regardless of skill or expertise).

item.title: File Formats
item.description: When it comes to publishing, services generally accept or output 4 formats. Word documents (.doc or .docx) PDF documents (.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: Congratulations on finishing the course about publishing! Hopefully it gave useful advice about how to sell and market a book, whether it’s to a literary agent (to get published traditionally) or to your audience (when self-publishing).
